Identifying Characteristics: Shell is striped and/or zigzagged rings/bands
Very light or white shell with dark concentric rings on shell
Very light color at the hinge
Valves are asymmetrical when viewed from ventricle side
Size: Adults can be up to 4cm long
Biology: Intense filter feeders resulting in the accumulation of pseudofeces—increase water acidity and produces toxic byproducts
Produce organic toxins and pollutants, which get passed up the food chain
Threaten local ecosystems as they colonize and smother other species
Diet: Remove suspended particulates from the water column through filter feeding—phytoplankton, zooplankton, algae, and sometimes their own veligers
Habitat: Can inhabit both soft and hard substrates
Ideal water temperatures are around 28 degrees Celsius and depth of habitat depends on water temperature
Range: Native: Dneiper River drainage of Ukraine and Ponto-Caspian Sea

Invasive: United States—Great Lakes, Iowa, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, and Pennsylvania, the Ohio River, the Mississippi River, California, Arizona, Nevada, Colorado, Utah, New Mexico
